Summary To play a leading role in a growing software organization to advance the state-of-the-art in all aspects of software engineering.

Experience Senior Release Engineer Google March 2013  – Present (2 years 6 months) Mountain View, CA In 2013 I joined the Android Build and Release team as an individual contributor working to help improve the quality and velocity of Android OS platform and unbundled app releases, and to improve the existing automation/infrastructure to accomplish these aims. 
 
I also help facilitate two internal People Dev leadership programs: one is a 3-day immersion for the next generation of Google engineering leaders (since 2009) and the other is an Adaptive Leadership 3-day course for senior staff and higher grade employees throughout the company (since 2012). I also perform on-demand leadership coaching for alumni of these programs. 
 
Finally, I occasionally cook with the Google and former Google culinary teams including offsite catering and charity events. Senior Engineering Manager Google October 2005  –  March 2013  (7 years 6 months) Mountain View, CA I started my Google career as a Senior Tools Strategist working in the Eng Infrastructure Build & Tools team. My primary responsibilities were to be a change agent for core Google infrastructure and create runway with existing infrastructure to allow long-term disruptive changes to take hold. Since 2007 I began managing a team that helped architect massive performance and scalability improvements to the SCM systems used internally by every engineer in the company, world-wide. 
 
From 2009 – 2013 I managed a basket of teams in the Developer Infrastructure group that focused on source code management and operations, and release platforms and automation. I also sat on an SET/TE/RE hiring committee, served as the 24x7 on-call escalation point for all infrastructure teams that I managed, coordinated with Legal on urgent SCM court-ordered discovery requests, helped drive the annual company-wide disaster readiness exercise, and served as the SOX POC for a subset of SCM/RE services. Senior Tools Strategist Microsoft May 2000  –  September 2005  (5 years 5 months) Mountain View, CA I was a front-line manager working in the MSN TV division supporting the MSN TV family of internet on TV products. My responsibilities included investigating and implementing large-scale improvements to the core build and tools infrastructure. I also recommended, managed, architected, mentored, and implemented changes to the build processes, the tools, the system architecture, and the documentation to address core issues. I had overarching responsibility for cross-group collaboration with other MSN TV teams, the MSTV build/tools teams, the Windows CE build/tools team, and the MSN Core team. Software Architect, Director of Software Development, Manager of Engineering Infrastructure Talarian Corporation June 1998  –  May 2000  (2 years) Los Altos, CA As a Software Architect, my responsibilities were to design, implement, and integrate server-to-server multicast for the company’s flagship product, SmartSockets on an extremely tight schedule. As Director of Product Development, I oversaw a team of product developers as the consensus builder and issue resolver. My responsibilities included defining, prioritizing, and documenting product features, creating and maintaining project schedules, coordinating release schedules with other departments, collaborating with people at all levels in the company, recruiting, budgeting, and performance reviews. As the Manager of Engineering Infrastructure, I was responsible for producing the core build infrastructure for the SmartSockets family of products. Vice President Tri-Pacific Consulting Corporation July 1994  –  June 1998  (4 years) Alameda, CA I was a co-owner, officer, and director of this company whose major business objectives are to provide elite C, C++, UNIX, Windows (both 95/98 and NT), RMA (Rate Monotonic Analysis), and Real-Time CORBA consulting and training services. My primary role at the company was to expand its business through a subsidiary named Tri-Pacific Software that develops GUI real-time, embedded system analysis modeling tools based on RMA and RT CORBA. As Vice President, I was responsible for: 
 
(1) managing all engineering activities related to Tri-Pacific Software’s product line, 
 
(2) consulting at Sun Microsystems (SunSoft), 
 
(3) managing all UNIX and RMA consulting/training activities, and 
 
(4) daily involvement in the strategic aspects of running the company. Executive Vice President Systems Engineering Research Corp June 1990  –  June 1994  (4 years 1 month) Mountain View, VA I was a co-founder of this company that produces commercial X Window and Motif bindings and tools between the Ada83 and C programming languages. The company also provides C, UNIX, X Window, and Ada83 training and consulting services. As executive vice president, officer, and director, I had ultimate responsibility for all engineering activities and personnel. Also, I had daily hands-on involvement in all phases of engineering activities including product design and development; workstation/network installation, administration, and maintenance; contract programmer activities; and training seminars. In 1991 and 1992, I reengineered SunSoft's gxv and golit tools for inclusion with the SunAda compiler (under contract with Sun Microsystems). Computer Systems Lab Research Staff Stanford University October 1985  –  September 1990  (5 years) Stanford, CA I was a member of the technical staff in the Program Analysis and Verification Group. Responsibilities included development of experimental languages (ANNA, TSL) that supported software specification and verification techniques, interaction with industry affiliates, development of software environments to prove the feasibility of the underlying research, and UNIX expertise. During this tenure, I also performed contract programming, consulting, and training seminars to many companies. I was also a key player responsible for evaluating, recommending, installing, configuring, and maintaining the first network of Sun3 workstations and file servers (Sun3/110, SunOS 3.5) in the department of Electrical Engineering (1986). Software Engineer Lockheed Missiles & Space Co., Inc. April 1984  –  October 1985  (1 year 7 months) Sunnyvale, CA MILSTAR: I was a software designer in the ground support group for this military satellite communications system. Software Technology Support Lab: Duties included intra-company consulting, research, product evaluations, training, and technical presentations and publications. Summary Richard DeBlasio 
 
Research Fellow Emeritus 
 
Richard (Dick) DeBlasio is an expert in renewable electricity, end use systems applications, and distributed energy resources. 
 
 Biography  
 
Mr. Richard DeBlasio is a NREL Research Fellow and NREL chief engineer for Power Systems Engineering. Mr. DeBlasio has over 50 years of experience and has held various senior level positions at NREL for over 38 years including: serving as the NREL/DOE electricity principal program and technology manager from 1996 to 20011 and earlier as the PI for the NREL Photovoltaics Module and System Engineering Project from 1978 to 1996. Before joining NREL (SERI) in 1978, he was a senior nuclear engineer with the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission in Washington, D.C. (1974 to 1978), a project manager with UL (1972-1974), and a member of the nuclear engineering research staff at Stanford University (1965-1972). Mr.. DeBlasio is a graduate of Santa Clara University and Temple University, completed the MIT nuclear reactor safety program; was a licensed research reactor operator, and served in the U.S. Air Force as a radar/electronics specialist from 1961 to 1965. Mr. DeBlasio is an electrical/electronics engineer, a life senior member of the IEEE and former member of the IEEE Standards Board and Board of Governors (2008-2011), (lead the IEEE 1547 and 2030 for interoperability) and former chair of the IEC TC82 on Solar PV Systems international standards. Is Co-Editor of the International Journal of DER; Awarded the NREL Van Morriss Award in 2004 for outstanding leadership and sustained dedication to the growth and development of Distributed Energy and Electric Reliability Programs. He is the 2010 recipient of the IEEE Charles Proteus Steinmetz Medal for contributions to the standardization and global impact of distributed electric power system technology. He also received the 2011 American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Finnegan Standards Medal for extraordinary leadership
